entry.title: Support for Karabakh refugees renews after public pressure

media:group.media:title: Support for Karabakh refugees renews after public pressure
media:group.media:description:
üìç The Armenian government extended key social assistance programs for forcibly displaced families from Nagorno-Karabakh by two months, responding to demands from protesters. üìç Amnesty International‚Äôs annual global report highlighted ongoing human rights concerns in Armenia, including restrictions on free speech and peaceful assembly, challenges faced by Nagorno-Karabakh refugees, and tensions with Azerbaijan. It also praised the recent legislation cracking down on domestic violence. üìç Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan delivered a sharp message in a cabinet meeting against government inaction in various sectors. Meanwhile, Justice Minister Srbuhi Galyan announced that the government plans to introduce fixed deadlines for court cases to put an end to years-long delays that have plagued the legal system. üìç Armenia trails neighbors in developing relations with China: https://www.civilnet.am/en/news/947502/armenia-trails-neighbors-in-developing-relations-with-china/

entry.title: The World Bank has a new strategy for Armenia

media:group.media:title: The World Bank has a new strategy for Armenia
media:group.media:description:
Carolin Geginat, country manager for the World Bank in Armenia, talks to CivilNet about the newly released Country Partnership Framework, a five-year strategy aiming to reduce poverty and improve resilience across Armenia. She outlines how the World Bank plans to prioritize the more than $1 billion fund taking into consideration Armenia's varied challenges. Geginat also explains how the Bank plans to mobilize private capital investments, navigate climate change concerns, and build human capital as part of Armenia‚Äôs path toward long-term development.

üìç Georgia‚Äôs President Mikheil Kavelashvili describes a new peak in relations with Armenia. üìç Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan and Estonian Prime Minister Kristen Michal pledge deeper cooperation in digitalization, reforms, and EU integration during Pashinyan‚Äôs official visit to Tallinn. üìç Following activist complaints, Armenia‚Äôs Investigative Committee is probing pro-government figures over alleged hate speech targeting Nagorno-Karabakh refugees. üìç Low cost and high quality fuel Armenia‚Äôs medical tourism boom- https://youtu.be/Zfvr8LvL4U4

entry.title: Europe‚Äôs moment for building peace in the South Caucasus

media:group.media:title: Europe‚Äôs moment for building peace in the South Caucasus
media:group.media:description:
Dr. Marat Terterov, co-founder of the Brussels Energy Club and the European Geopolitical Forum, discusses the current situation of the European Union‚Äôs relations with the South Caucasian countries- Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia. He also explains his vision for regional cooperation in the South Caucasus, and the steps needed to discourage conflict and foster stability.

media:group.media:title: Why Armenia must electrify #shorts
media:group.media:description:
With around 80% of its total primary energy supply dependent on imports, Armenia faces a critical challenge in securing its energy future, making efficiency and diversification central to its strategy. An extensive electrification program could address this issue.
